question: Question_01_(c)
statement:
Express $\lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{i^{4}}{n^{5}}$ as a
definite integral. Do not evaluate this integral.
sols:
Notice that our question is equivalent to

$\lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{i^{4}}{n^{5}}  = \lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{1}{n} \cdot \frac{i^{4}}{n^{4}}$

The values for the Riemann sum look like

$\displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{1}{n} = \frac{b-a}{n}$

$\displaystyle x_{i} = 0 + \frac{i}{n}  = \frac{i}{n}$

and so

$\displaystyle a = 0$

and so with the above in the $\Delta x$, we can deduce that

$\displaystyle b = 1$

and our function should be

$f(x) = x^{4}$

Hence, we have

$\lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{i^{4}}{n^{5}}  = \int_{0}^{1}x^{4}\, dx$

completing the question.
hints: This is a Riemann sum problem. Try isolating a factor of $\frac{1}{n}$

The values should look like

$\displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{1}{n}$

$\displaystyle x_{i} = \frac{i}{n}$

and so

$\displaystyle a = 0$

See if you can determine the rest of the values.
